results.title: Drink Deep
results.brief_description: Drink Deep is a lyrical vision of friendship, hidden secrets, and desires. Cohen uses several types of film image to add texture to the layered composition. Beautiful shades of grey, silver, black and blue echo the water, reminiscent of early photography and silverprints. Cohen says, “The piece was constructed primarily from footage I’d shot of skinnydippers at swimming holes in Georgia and rural Pennsylvania. It’s about water and memory and stories just submerged. It is also, in part, a response to thinking about censorship. I would say that Drink Deep is both unabashedly and deceptively romantic. Surface, flow, and undertow. What looks like paradise is always paradise lost.” Music composed by Stephen Vitiello and performed with Gabriel Cohen and Mary Wooten.

results.title: Janus. Eps 23 and 24: Breach of bond. An Unnatural act
results.creator_credit: Julian McSwiney, Robert Klenner, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 23 and 24 of the television series Janus. “Breach of bond” (48 mins) (directed by Robert Klenner). Shane Hennessey (Jonathan Kernut) has broken his 12 month bond and finds himself remanded in custody on charges of robbery causing injury intentionally, theft and possession of a drug of dependence. Once again he faces Glenda de Bono (Louise Siversen), the same magistrate who put him on a bond for his previous offences. Glenda de Bono also hears a case against a family of gypsies involving crystal balls, curses and large payments of cash. “An Unnatural act” (50 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney) focuses on a disturbing case of incest where a father has allegedly raped his 10-year-old daughter. Michael Kidd acts as Defence Counsellor for the father with Tina Bertrum prosecuting on behalf of the daughter, Evie (Leah de Niese). Meanwhile an escaped prisoner who has been recaptured could be Peter Faithful’s answer to the final missing link in the murder case against Mal Hennessey. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Tracy Mann, Paulene Terry-Beitz, and Ezra Bix.

results.title: Black Hole Radio
results.brief_description:
Over the past 20 years, filmmaker Jem Cohen has assembled a massive visual archive of Super 8 and 16mm by filming everyday images and experiences as he negotiates his way through the spaces of New York City. Filled with enigmatic glimpses, gestures and images seeming to come from half-remembered dreams, memories and snatches of conversations, this archive contains hints for unearthing the many secrets of contemporary metropolitan life.
In the mid 1990s Cohen encountered a series of advertisements for a New York City ‘Phone Confession Line’.To call in and confess was free; to listen cost money. Cohen acquired recordings of these taped confessions of murderous thoughts, desire and treachery, and used them to form the audio heartbeat of his video installation ‘Black Hole Radio’. Accompanied by ghostly Super 8 images filmed by the artist during his nocturnal wanderings, the installation reveals the anonymous lives and restless spirits that haunt the phonelines, televisions and sleepless nights of the city.
For this version of the installation, ACMI has worked with the artist to create a small confessional cell where images shimmer like paranoid hallucinations while disturbing whispers hang in mid-air, semi-publicly. The elusive images that linger on the edge of visual perception provide the evidence of Cohen’s investigation into the small confessed ‘crimes’: loving the wrong man, harbouring hatred or greed. Visitors leave ‘Black Hole Radio’ feeling the way they do when a shameful memory wakes them in the dead of night. Inside Cohen’s confessional, it is understood that it is both a privilege and a curse: to live as social beings and to know that isolation and forgetting can’t conceal the troubled heart of the city.

results.title: Goldeneye
results.creator_credit: Martin Campbell, Barbara Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
When a deadly satellite weapon falls into the wrong hands, only Agent 007 (Pierce Brosnan) can save the world from certain disaster. Armed with his license to kill and his smooth talking ways, Bond races to Russia in search of the stolen access codes for “GoldenEye”, the devastating satellite weapon. James Bond is pitted against an enemy who knows his every movement, a former agent, 006, trained in exactly the same methods and who can anticipate his every move. Alec Trevelyan (Sean Bean), agent 006 is motivated by a hatred that goes back years. 006 is not the only person causing Bond grief, he also battles with his former compatriot’s stunning ally, Xenia Onatopp (Famke Janssen), who crushes victims between her shapely but deadly thighs.

results.title: Janus. Eps 17 and 18: Right to remain silent. My learned friend, Mr Hennessey
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 17 and 18 of the television series Janus. “Right to remain silent” (51 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith). The internal investigation into the shooting of Steve Hennessey continues. Meantime, Roz Breen (Jeanette Cronin) who has been charged with smuggling drugs into prison, decides to fight the case. Her defence is “duress”, caused by intimidation and fear of the Hennessey family. Although Steve is dead, the drug trafficking connection still lives on. “My learned friend, Mr Hennessey” (52 mins) (directed by Michael Carson) shows Mal Hennessey (Brett Swain) in a somewhat different light to the usual cold, indifferent violent person that he can be, as he defends himself in a commital hearing on a charge of “Breach of prison” relating to his escape from the Police Van. With Shirl Hennessey still in Fairlea and no money to pay Michael Kidd to defend him, Mal has to take on the system. And take on the system he does, much to Vic Manoulis’s frustration and Peter Faithful’s growing concern. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Leverne McDonnell, Simon Chilvers, Paul Gleeson.

results.title: Janus. Eps 11 and 12: Without prejudice. Improper influences
results.creator_credit: Julian McSwiney, Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 11 and 12 of the television series Janus. “Without prejudice” (50 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) gives an insight to jury selection procedures and the workings of a jury during a trial. Steve Hennessey (Leon Teague) and Darren Mack (Nique Needles) are finally being tried for “trafficking of drugs of dependence” with Dale Cassidy (previously a Prosecution witness at the commital hearing) now appearing as the main witness for the Prosecution. Peter Faithful and Rob Griffin are slowly mounting evidence against Mal Hennessey for the murder of Patrick Clancy. “Improper influences” (48 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney). Judge Grossman (Denis Moore) is determined to see the Steve Hennessey drug trial through, despite growing concern about his health. Defence’s case focuses on the questionable quality of the police surveillance video-tape of the drug deal. Peter Faithful’s unrelenting pursuit of evidence to get Mal Hennessey for murder leads him to Mal’s ex-girlfriend who is serving time in Fairlea Women’s Prison. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Grant Piro, Sheryl Munks, Damian Foley, Greg Fleet and Pepe Trevor.
results.title_for_label: Janus. Eps 11 and 12: Without prejudice. Improper influences
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julian McSwiney, Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 11 and 12 of the television series Janus. “Without prejudice” (50 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) gives an insight to jury selection procedures and the workings of a jury during a trial. Steve Hennessey (Leon Teague) and Darren Mack (Nique Needles) are finally being tried for “trafficking of drugs of dependence” with Dale Cassidy (previously a Prosecution witness at the commital hearing) now appearing as the main witness for the Prosecution. Peter Faithful and Rob Griffin are slowly mounting evidence against Mal Hennessey for the murder of Patrick Clancy. “Improper influences” (48 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney). Judge Grossman (Denis Moore) is determined to see the Steve Hennessey drug trial through, despite growing concern about his health. Defence’s case focuses on the questionable quality of the police surveillance video-tape of the drug deal. Peter Faithful’s unrelenting pursuit of evidence to get Mal Hennessey for murder leads him to Mal’s ex-girlfriend who is serving time in Fairlea Women’s Prison. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Grant Piro, Sheryl Munks, Damian Foley, Greg Fleet and Pepe Trevor.

results.title: Goldeneye (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Martin Campbell, Barbara Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson, United Artists Corporation and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Pierce Brosnan ignites the screen as the legendary James Bond in this explosive, thrill-packed adventure that hits the bulls-eye for nonstop excitement. When a deadly satellite weapon system falls into the wrong hands, only agent 007 can save the world from certain disaster. Cast includes Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco and Famke Janssen.

results.title: Janus. Eps 05 and 06: Judgement amongst short men. Reckless indifference
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 5 and 6 of the television series Janus. “Judgement amongst short men” (47 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith) focuses on two court cases, the first one relating to a rape case involving a prostitute and a questionably lenient sentence given to the rapist and the other case, Rhonda Hennessey standing accused for attempting to pervert the course of justice. Rhonda Hennessey’s trial follows on from her attempts to threaten Kirsty Nichols (Steve Hennessey’s pregnant girlfriend) when Kirsty, turned police informant, was to give evidence against the Hennessey family. “Reckless indifference” (47 mins) (directed by Michael Carson) revolves around the youngest son of the Hennessey family, Shane Hennessey (Jonathan Kernutt) and his refusal after being charged with attempted murder, theft of a stolen vehicle, reckless conduct etc to admit his identity to the police or to the Court. Rather than being afraid of police reaction, Shane is far more concerned and frightened of his brother Mal. He chooses to face the charges alone, rather than go to his family for help. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Tracy Mann, Louise Siversen, Belinda McClory, Leverne McDonnell, Jane Menelaus, Frank Magree, Ezra Bix and Jonathan Kernutt.

results.title: Dr. No
results.creator_credit: Ken Adam, Terence Young, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Dr. No was the first extraordinary adventure of the world’s most famous spy: James Bond. Sean Connery is 007: suave, charming and fearless; an expert on weapons, women, martinis and just about everything. Dr. No, a fanatical scientist, is a member of the terrorist organisation SPECTRE, which plans to conquer the world. However, thanks to the daring of James Bond, Dr. No is ultimately defeated. Ursula Andress made her screen debut in the film. While there is no famous title song, the well-known James Bond theme, elaborate opening title sequences by Maurice Binder and the magnificent locations were present from this first film and have now become part of the James Bond legend.

results.title: Janus. Eps 21 and 22: Demands with menaces. Fit to plead
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 21 and 22 of the television series Janus. “Demands with menaces” (50 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith) finds Peter Faithful in the hot seat again. Rhonda Hennessey’s (Victoria Eagger) husband, Darren Mack (Nique Needles) is to stand trial at a committal hearing for attempted extortion on a fellow inmate at Pentridge. Allegations are made about Peter Faithful’s involvement with the victim, Zoglin (Raj Sidhu) at the police interview and Faithful offering support to Zoglin in a bail application. Michael Kidd argues on the premise of the Hennessey connection, that Darren Mack is part of the Hennessey family and subsequently a target for Peter Faithful’s ongoing investigation into the Hennessey’s. “Fit to plead” (52 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) follows two separate court scenarios. One involving Darren Mack attending his sentencing hearing and the other, an Aboriginal prisoner, Ray Crundall (David Ngoombujarra) being tried for assault. Defence Counsellor, Kathy Tainsh (Glenda Linscott) finds herself fighting the system for justice and understanding on behalf of her Aboriginal client, and Darren Mack decides to fight the system himself, sacking his Defence Counsellor and going it alone. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Felix Nobis, Steve Hardman, Tracy Mann, and Alex Scott.
